title: Elementary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - Ethics and Religious Culture (2010)
subject: Personal Development

document.title: Elementary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - Ethics and Religious Culture (2010)

C197FD8990CD48569F544FB8C01D6612.description: an appeal to the people (e.g. how does the fact that all your friends can stay out until 9:00 p.m. mean that you can too?)

0A3F2BBF86714EDBBF073BA6B952C6B9.description: a personal attack (e.g. do you think you are helping the discussion by calling someone a baby?)

60A5603B727D4121BBA3BA1F4A5BBFE3.description: a hasty generalization (e.g. do all cats eat more when they are alone or when they are bored?)

0E6872588CF4428C89BE6CF38ECF12FE.description: Examines, in a situation involving dialogue:

0CD167D4AAEB45F3A3C1F71BD5E7C3DE.description: an appeal to the people (e.g. all my friends can stay out until 9:00 p.m., so I can too)

FCFC2602BF47444A9B37D7C6C4B6C1D6.description: a personal attack (e.g. you're too much of a baby to understand this)

A4C3728092D3428CAB7528FC33470103.description: a hasty generalization (e.g. when my cat is home alone, he eats more; therefore cats who are bored eat more)

001B8C76C21D4F98A0C0C727B8E60ECD.description: Recognizes, in a situation involving dialogue:

93129313E0D4472DA62480BE8D983819.description: a hasty generalization, a personal attack

4BEA3C85845048C18418E56E316C9810.description: a judgment of reality (e.g. can you explain how the date for the Easter celebration is decided?)

8D9B80572D1349E79402CED816C87786.description: a judgment of prescription (e.g. why does this regulation exist?)

159F365625FA43829F92F0E582E0F63C.description: a judgment of preference (e.g. can you explain why you prefer winter?)

73918E690BA84C04820D1A2117E1AD62.description: Examines, in a situation involving dialogue:

116ACB8674A448538971D8B056FE0287.description: a judgment of reality (e.g. the Easter celebration takes place in spring, but not on a set date)

8DAD28593E1D4B98A35AB18A0E58CEAF.description: a judgment of prescription (e.g. the regulation prohibits running around the swimming pool)

B079E62C1858402BA818ED352EAC49FD.description: a judgment of preference (e.g. winter is my favourite season; it's the most beautiful season)

2023EB29169D46C9AE08D5A866CDB97D.description: Recognizes, in a situation involving dialogue:

6ACE038BD7DE48E8AFE749357716536E.description: a judgment of preference, a judgment of prescription

DD21593A367244FA81D39F7E25EC3FC1.description: Explains, in his/her own words the meaning of:

AE3A5AE2020040AD81FF49FA6E061DF7.description: Means for examining a point of view

AAA5F7D1AE4848FDA5CD1B20A89675B0.description: Uses explanation to help others to know or understand the meaning of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle Two, explains the negative effects of intimidation by referring to what a community police officer said; in Cycle Three, explains the connections between rights and responsibilities by referring to charters, city regulations and the school code)

EECF8BE7B16E481BAF32C15AC8D27F74.description: Describes, in his/her own words, what an explanation is (e.g. explaining means providing accurate information to account for how I understand something)

5F9EA9ED3DEC40B993BDFE39EB21F09B.description: Uses synthesis to provide a coherent summary of the elements of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle Two, summarizes his/her discoveries about different ways of celebrating civil marriage or religious marriage; in Cycle Three, summarizes his/her understanding of the founding events of a religious tradition)

4575C24C6B1041FA8E26C709700468C0.description: Explains, in his/her own words, what synthesis is (e.g. making a synthesis means summarizing what has been discussed)

2ACEC92F8BD84757B66DF648AD14A1DD.description: Uses comparison to highlight similarities and differences among the elements of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, names two differences between the needs of animals and those of a human being; in Cycle Two, compares an advantage and a disadvantage of playing alone and in a group; in Cycle Three, compares how children's rights are observed in various areas of the world)

909536B5923A48F5AB1E8A4DE4D45C75.description: Explains, in his/her own words, what comparison is (e.g. drawing a comparison means finding differences and similarities between two things)

5A90C2CCDE5947A8BC5BDC57249FA0B1.description: Uses description to enumerate the characteristics of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, words, objects or gestures for a ritual associated with birth; in Cycle Two, various parts of a place of worship and objects, furnishings and symbols; in Cycle Three, origin, division of time, main markers of time for a calendar)

D8053F5160534F8F9057FA733E9F17F0.description: Explains, in his/her own words, what description is (e.g. giving a description means giving several characteristics of something)

9FBE5F6E176540FB90D8743CCD056ED1.description: Means for developing a point of view

A1099A62EC6C427499A5E5B108734513.description: all other paths for fostering dialogue

C9993D3C85B54AED9BAF14A566B87AAD.description: attentively listens to what another person has to say in order to grasp the meaning

2FEF800903FF44D4B207391F8E424845.description: respects the right of others to speak

EB71B3FAEB9240B09FDA0E633B3D56E6.description: observes rules for engaging in dialogue

23E4731AD5524E56BBFCF9C1AC770F26.description: Uses, in a situation involving dialogue:

67DF812A7F4D4508B05B06BA6FF25786.description: Explains, in his/her own words, the meaning of:

9E042C80155C4EA69B77C10B01CBCBD0.description: Knowledge related to the practice of dialogue

8260BC094576498FA59EE187FA5B6E82.description: Associates forms of religious expression with their religious tradition (e.g. the wayside cross and Christianity; a tombstone bearing the Star of David and Judaism; the peace-pipe and Native spirituality)

69577D5F5477478C8F9760C5C25DE39A.description: Associates symbols and images with various representations of the world's origins (e.g. representations of earthly paradise, the turtle representing Mother Earth)

678358B8DBCE4F3DA9BEE65AEADF3521.description: Describes community or cultural works influenced by religion: characteristics, mission, impact in the community, etc.

ACDC93F3D5914AA6A11AFBB0B8B34AC8.description: Names community or cultural works influenced by religion (e.g. stained glass, paintings, sculptures as works of art; Saint Vincent de Paul Society as community work; media holiday food drive as a cultural event)

28B4860378E44275A66BE561618491B7.description: Describes forms of religious expression observed in the environment: what it is, what it represents, its use, appearance, origin, etc

F74811DDCB8A49C488801075A6ECDDC6.description: Names elements of religious heritage present in the environment (e.g. church bell, cemetery, names of certain streets)

47EC196234A24A2DB00A2C91A7B61AEB.description: Forms of religious expression in the young person's environment5

53F5FD242BD14D33BE8628F07942787C.description: Associates elements of a celebration experienced in a community with the appropriate religious tradition (e.g. the chalice and Christianity; Book of the Word and Protestantism; the tam-tam and Native spirituality; the three crows and Buddhism; the Vedas and Hinduism)

DE45EEB354C04DB6AF865B6B062F9363.description: Describes practices of prayer and meditation: places, words recited, gestures, songs, objects used

7FE4D9DA26114E0782DF3BA00F962454.description: Associates words and writings with their religious tradition (e.g. the Bible and Christianity; the Torah and Judaism; Jesus for Christianity; the Great Spirit and Native spirituality; Allah for Islam)

346D84954B404DDDB186645230DCAF03.description: Associates spiritual guides with one or more religious practices (e.g. the priest and the celebration of the Eucharist; the pastor and the assembly of prayer; the rabbi and the Sabbath prayers; the shaman and Native spirituality)

C12AD6B690A241488C61216E7CF43EA2.description: Describes religious celebrations experienced in the community: reasons for the celebration, gestures, words recited, objects used, etc.

E2C939D1FF9342559CFD3E2F5B38C203.description: Describes places of worship, objects or symbols connected with one or more religious practices (e.g. form, furnishings, decorations in the place of worship; form, colour, use of objects; form, origin, meaning of the symbols)

954240BA323A48C5A59FCDA444FF67CF.description: Names daily, weekly, annual or occasional religious celebrations (e.g. daily prayer, Sunday mass, Seder meal, marriage, funeral)

103ABC60FF2E455FA9DB8C89D5C28977.description: Associates stories with their religious tradition (e.g. the Nativity story and Christianity; the story of Glouskap and the story of Beaver who steals fire and Native spirituality; the birth of Gautama and Buddhism)

CB76FFE105644BA19DCF3E4CCBA4B56F.description: Names the important aspects of a story associated with a celebration or an key figure (e.g. the building of Noah’s ark, the animals, the rain, the dove, the rainbow in the story of Noah and the Flood)

925ED86A77EE48FDAD973EE843A93E2D.description: Associates stories with celebrations or key figures (e.g. the story of the Three Wise Men and the celebration of the Epiphany, the Exodus of the Jews from Egypt and the celebration of Succoth)

ACBDAF97E5D443C8A4BC8725666FADEF.description: Describes forms of religious expression associated with various stories: main aspects, form, colour, location where they take place, use, etc

21AF8AB7FFEE4A58B4F73A91B60C5DB1.description: Names forms of religious expression that are associated with various stories (e.g. the nativity scene, the galette des rois and the story of Jesus' birth, Native masks and stories)

9880E4BB81F147C595967C90F53547D1.description: Associates rituals associated with birth with their tradition of origin (e.g. baptism and Christianity; whispering the call to prayer and Islam)

9F06CB459A7C4A5B9278A7869ECA836E.description: Associates celebrations with their tradition of origin (e.g. Christmas and Christianity, Passover and Judaism, powwow and Native traditions, the secular celebration of Mother's Day)

7DBAB0A1F26A47068711939464CF3585.description: Describes rituals associated with birth: locations for the rituals, gestures, words, people present, etc

F91AA71FF3C8496DB19735966B5071A8.description: Names rituals associated with birth2 (e.g. baptism, walking out ceremony, planting a tree)

38DA18AFAB9041C286557BCE9276ECBC.description: Describes ways of experiencing family celebrations: how the celebration is held, special decorations, special menu, guests, etc.

96F610FCF3BC457D814A0011DBF1352D.description: Names celebrations (e.g. Easter, Hanukkah, Mother's Day, Diwali, birthdays)

224B906DD83F4737801198CD7BE1A120.description: Knowledge related to themes of religious culture

DEB01018300C4D1091461636536FBFC9.description: Formulates ethical questions (e.g. what is a just society, what does "being equal" mean?)

3608A991E5D34041A7958697C42A83CD.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, spiritual leaders, media)

074749689C4E4E11AC5C2353B0D60C87.description: Learning common to all themes at the elementary level

961770C414024069B16EF8E40A09C8D4.description: Names the conditions that foster the personal well-being of the members of a group (e.g. sharing material in the classroom, establishing a conflict-management procedure)

9F843FFC7D3F45F19FA6BDE2885269E3.description: Names the roles and responsibilities that members of a group may assume (e.g. in a drama group, all actors have to memorize their parts)

08A7BE5B6A0D444EB2B33033BA1E2AAF.description: Gives examples of situations in which values or norms can be questioned, modified or improved to foster community life (e.g. although keeping a secret is usually a good idea, sometimes, to help a friend, a secret should be revealed to an adult)

573207A1001742CF838033AF2DB20DE7.description: Explains how norms guide group life (e.g. in karate classes, the teacher asks everyone to change teammates on a regular basis to avoid creating subgroups)

1EB63AEC6E8E48AAB2B5EFF177C88982.description: Explains how values guide group life (e.g. the value of respect encourages students to wait their turn to speak and allows everyone to express an opinion without being interrupted)

021E9DECA29446A9BE45605AAEAF9B0D.description: Explains how behaviours, attitudes or actions can detract from group life (e.g. insulting a friend, or talking behind his/her back creates tension in the group and can cause conflicts)

99D939438629490DBB6CAAFC50022BEA.description: Explains how behaviours, attitudes or actions can foster group life (e.g. by adopting a calm attitude in class, everyone contributes to creating a pleasant atmosphere conducive to work, and the whole group benefits)

6A623793D3B94CBB9409CDF67D6A4803.description: Demands of belonging to a group

0AC6DAE8D61842A3993D9069AA4D1E90.description: Explains how interpersonal relationships can contribute to or detract from the personal development of group members (e.g. when the captain of a team encourages the players, the players feel appreciated and this reinforces their self-esteem; a player who feels rejected by the members of his/her team loses self-confidence)

AE8AE525C18849FD8EFE9D3A1F2F55B6.description: Names various types of relationships that can exist among the members of a group (e.g. friendship, leadership and conflictual relationships can exist among classmates)

A2DC3062892649FCA4B3EAC00D8C3B41.description: Gives examples of situations illustrating the disadvantages of group life (e.g. since many students want to play on the play structure, they all have to be patient and wait their turn, make compromises and learn to share the space)

BDCDBB99569F4914BAFBE988A43818FD.description: Gives examples of situations illustrating the advantages of group life (e.g. through the cooperation and solidarity of all students in the school, the school yard cleanup was done quickly and everyone had more time to play)

252E4BE400C34054BB7790663D0C3C01.description: Gives examples of situations where needs are met in a group (e.g. by celebrating my birthday, my friends and my family meet my need to be loved and be recognized)

3B2CC8C5AF694C84A3C1B2DAEC2A753B.description: Makes connections between belonging to a group or groups and the development of personal identity (e.g. influence of a group of friends on musical tastes, influence of family on recreational activities, belonging to a scout troop and the ability to survive in a forest)

8AFF46B3791D4DFF9E7FAEB0EE930E78.description: Names the groups to which people belong4 (e.g. family, class, friends, sports team, drama group, choir)

72D6015848474B7F9ACBB837E8441A3C.description: Names people or groups who take action to protect living beings (e.g. police officers, school crossing guards, Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals)

69DE2E8FE8CE4136AAAB7B38128909C7.description: Gives examples of actions that can harm living beings (e.g. saying hurtful things, hitting an animal, ripping a plant out of the soil)

C624EE9AB82A40849F8560F6ABBE396A.description: Gives examples of actions that may foster the well-being of living beings (e.g. consoling a friend, sharing toys, feeding a pet)

3EC4DD7006054EADBC44279C47BD08EB.description: Names the norms that guide behaviour in families and at school (e.g. bedtime, rules of conduct in class)

7DEC93A570834AA3ADF74BD84E1FBB9D.description: Names the values that guide behaviour in families and at school (e.g. sharing, attention to others, safety, respect)

4183B7B08D054CB8951D7C38D7CF621D.description: Names the responsibilities that different people at school may assume (e.g. a student is responsible for cleaning the board; the principal organizes parent-teacher meetings; the secretary records absences)

2E5A2E7C69BA4B6295677ED251C0A27A.description: Names the responsibilities that different family members may assume (e.g. parents are responsible for feeding their children; a child might be responsible for walking the dog)

C415723D095B4D688EC01993E46EA962.description: Demands associated with the interdependence of humans and other living beings

5291934224A24114B54DF127FE16413D.description: Gives examples of actions illustrating that the members of a family need each other (e.g. children need parents to give them shelter; parents need their children to cooperate to create a pleasant living environment)

D3D6385530784306AA8CC3CA55270521.description: Gives examples of actions illustrating that living beings need each other (e.g. the farmer grows the vegetables I eat)

F4394AF991C541EDAC119A0E9FCFA1C0.description: Names the needs that are not shared by plants, animals and human beings (e.g. human being's need for clothing, in contrast to animals and plants)

E39AC267A62A492B9EE8709654560E8F.description: Names the needs shared by plants, animals and human beings (e.g. need for food)

893758307E5F43CD98DCDC1E715C454C.description: Names the elements that contribute to the unique character of each human being (e.g. personal history, preferences, talents, physical characteristics)

099BDECB7CAA4DE9AAC1D8E061A7787E.description: The needs of humans and other living beings
